ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The class was held live on zoom on M/W/F and was asynchronous on T/Th. On those days, we usually just had a short list of extra assignments/textbook readings to complete for homework.
Two asynchronous days per week learn on own
The course met live virtually for three days per week and we were expected to teach ourselves asynchronously the other two days.

All of our classes were conducted over Zoom in a seminar and discussion format. Quizzes and tests were conducted on Canvas and some of them required our presence in Zoom meeting. After purchasing the materials necessary for this class, we had access to a website with set homework from our instructor, which was very helpful since it was clear and helped me practice the content of lessons.
none
live CLS tutor

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained a basic understanding of the present and past tenses in Spanish. This course helped me develop reading, speaking, writing, and listening skills in both tenses. By the end of the semester, I was able to say and write coherent (albeit elementary) paragraphs in Spanish and read basic short works.
Good, basic Spanish foundation
I learned the basic knowledge of forming sentences and questions in Spanish. I also learned cultural information about Spanish speaking countries.
I started this course with no knowledge of Spanish. Therefore it was easy to track my progress and I believe I improved a lot in this language as I was able to complete this course.
I learned Spanish vocabulary, grammar, and gained familiarity with speaking in Spanish.
I learned basic Spanish
In this course, I developed a basic familiarity with Spanish and focused on vocabulary, verb tenses, history, sentence structure, and pronunciation.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: There are countless opportunities (literally every day of class) to practice your Spanish skills with the professor throughout the semester. Maripaz gives thorough feedback every time a student says or writes anything in Spanish, which was extremely helpful in developing better grammar and pronunciation. The syllabus very clearly lays out what is expected each day. The homework was a good way to practice the skills we were working on and having two attempts on many of the assignments was great. Weaknesses: This is not so much a weakness as just something to be aware of, but the class moves extremely fast.
Maripaz is an amazing professor, set up well for learning

The course has a lot of busywork, especially over Zoom, making it really difficult to stay engaged and interested in the material. Additionally, the asynchronous days were really difficult to keep up with material.

The whole course was very clearly structured before the semester even started. Every class, including work outside of class, was carefully described on the syllabus. This made following the material and studying much easier. This also helped with my time management, as I knew exactly when I need to do homework for this class. 

I can't think of any weaknesses.
I liked breakout rooms in class so that we could have conversations in Spanish, and not answer one line questions.
The strengths of this course was the syllabus and always knowing what homework was going to be due.
In my opinion, the biggest strength of SPAN 110 is that we meet in a discussion style seminar three times a week. The frequency of our synchronous classes allowed me to improve my Spanish.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The half synchronous/half asynchronous format was great. I was surprised at how engaging the class was as a whole despite being on Zoom. There were always dozens of chances to participate in each class by completing example questions. The use of breakout rooms was excellent and a great chance to practice Spanish skills in a smaller group setting. I also thought activities such as Kahoot to prepare for exams were great for engagement.
Only 3 days a week on zoom was helpful

In the lesson, we were taking turns in practicing grammar and the topics we learned. This allowed everyone to contribute equally to the class discussion and being able to gain from it too. Everybody had a chance to ask questions and be corrected.
Going through fillable worksheets one answer at a time did not keep me engaged. Breakout rooms and working on the same google drive answering questions was much better.
Having a partner on speaking projects was really helpful. I think the kahoot's worked well!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course to a student truly interested in developing basic Spanish skills. If you're looking for the easiest or lowest workload intro language course possible, this is probably not it. However, the class is completely manageable and the skills you gain by the end of the semester and the progress you are able to see yourself making are worth it.
Yes
Yes, I would because I believe it is a great course for beginners to learn Spanish. The content is adequate to the level and the instructor knows how to explain the content very well.
Yes. Spanish is a very useful language.
This is a great language course. Expect a high work load but it's extremely rewarding

I would definitely recommend SPAN 110 to a student who is either completely new to Spanish or minimally familiar with the language. After one semester, I believe that I learned more Spanish than I originally anticipated.
